# Forward Kinematics in Robotics: A Novel Neural Network Approach

## Introduction

In robotics, one crucial challenge is understanding the mapping relationship between joint space and end-effector pose space—known as the kinematics problem. This relationship is fundamental to both motion planning and control. The analysis becomes particularly challenging for robots with complex or closed-loop structures. The Gough-Stewart platform (GSP) [1], a classic parallel mechanism featuring a closed-loop design, exemplifies these challenges. Due to the unique characteristics of parallel robot structures, determining its forward kinematics can be exceptionally complex [2]. While researchers have proposed various solutions, no single method currently achieves both high precision and computational efficiency. This gap has driven continued research in the parallel manipulator community for more robust forward kinematics methods.

## Neural Network Applications

Neural networks (NNs) have emerged as a promising approach for learning mapping relationships and providing real-time solutions. In parallel manipulator research, this began with single-layer multi-layer perceptrons (MLPs) [3, 4]. Similar NN applications appear in studies of non-parallel structures [5, 6]. However, while NNs have opened new possibilities for solving complex mechanism kinematics, most implementations rely on basic MLPs using Euler angles for output representation. This traditional approach struggles to achieve high-precision pose outputs with limited datasets, primarily due to two factors:

1. Traditional MLPs exhibit weak inductive biases [7], though such biases are crucial for deep neural network advances
2. Direct rotation regression requires more sophisticated differentiable non-Euclidean representations beyond four dimensions [8]

## Our Novel Approach

Seeking to develop a network capable of both high-precision pose outputs and real-time solutions, we leverage the complex structure of parallel manipulators to construct a graph and apply message-passing graph neural networks (GNN). GNNs, known for their permutation equivariance, have demonstrated success across numerous fields [9]. However, implementing GNN techniques raises a crucial question: what input representation best serves forward kinematics learning? While GNNs typically use node coordinates as input features, these coordinates are not known a priori in forward kinematics. For the GSP, physical connection lengths are more readily available. We address this challenge by utilizing the graph distance matrix as GNN input.

## Technical Innovations

Recent research has highlighted traditional GNNs' limitations in effectively utilizing distance matrices for geometric learning [10-12], primarily due to their limited expressive power [12]. Building on Li et al.'s work [13] with k-WL/FWL algorithms and k-DisGNNs, we develop a highly expressive Distance Graph Neural Network (DisGNet) for forward kinematics learning. DisGNet employs 9D-SVD orthogonalization [15] for rotation representation, achieving high-precision pose outputs with parameter efficiency comparable to traditional MLP methods.

## Two-Stage Framework

To further enhance precision, we combine DisGNet with an optimized Newton-Raphson method, creating a novel two-stage framework (DisGNet + GPU-friendly Newton-Raphson), as illustrated in Fig. 1. Our GPU-friendly implementation accelerates computations by efficiently approximating the Moore-Penrose inverse through matrix-matrix multiplication, enabling real-time processing on GPU platforms.

## Key Contributions

1. Development of DisGNet: A highly expressive GNN optimized for learning geometric features from distances, delivering high-precision poses with efficient parameter usage
2. Implementation of GPU-friendly Newton-Raphson: A novel two-stage framework enabling ultra-high precision output and real-time forward kinematics solving
3. Introduction of refined evaluation metrics for forward kinematics learning models, accompanied by comprehensive dataset and benchmark results to benefit the parallel manipulator research community

# Des boulangers solidaires pour Benjamin

## L'histoire de Benjamin
En 2017, Sarah Gonzalez et Adrien Beau, agriculteurs à Ligny-le-Châtel, donnent naissance à un petit Benjamin. Quelques mois plus tard, des examens révèlent une paralysie des membres, le syndrome de Little. Au cours de leurs recherches, ils découvrent qu'il existe une solution : une intervention qui permettra à Benjamin d'améliorer sa marche et de supprimer les douleurs.

## Une intervention spécialisée en Allemagne
« L'opération, qui coûte 15.000 € et qui n'est pas prise en charge, sera réalisée par le professeur Haberl, à Bonn, en août », précise le papa. « Suivront des séances de kiné, pendant un an, évaluées à 35.000 €. » Cette intervention chirurgicale n'est pratiquée que par deux spécialistes dans le monde, l'un Américain, l'autre Allemand.

## La mobilisation des boulangers
L'Union des boulangers de l'Yonne s'est mobilisée en organisant un concours de galettes solidaire. Pour y participer, chaque concurrent devait faire un don au profit de l'association "Tous ensemble pour Benjamin". Jeudi, lors de leur présence à la chambre de métiers de l'Yonne pour l'évaluation du concours et leur assemblée générale, les membres présents ont remis, par l'intermédiaire de leur président Anthony Libault, un don de 550 €.

## Un espoir concret
Cette somme s'ajoute aux 50.000 € déjà collectés via une cagnotte en ligne. Désormais, l'espoir des parents de voir leur fils marcher normalement n'est plus lié à un problème d'argent mais repose sur les compétences du neurochirurgien et des kinés très spécialisés.

# Neural Machine Translation with Lexical Constraints: A Technical Overview

Neural machine translation (NMT) systems offer superior translation quality compared to phrase-based MT systems, but this advancement comes with a significant trade-off: reduced control over translation generation. The absence of explicit source-target vocabulary mapping makes it particularly challenging to enforce specific terminology in domain-specific translations.

Consider this practical example: A Chinese-English NMT system trained for e-commerce encounters the brand name "红米". Without prior exposure to this term in its training data, the system would literally translate it as "red (红) rice (米)" instead of the correct brand name "Redmi". To address such issues, translation professionals typically maintain domain-specific dictionaries to ensure accurate and consistent translations of specialized terms.

## Previous Approaches and Their Limitations

Researchers have pursued two main strategies to address this challenge:

1. **Model Re-training with Lexical Constraints**

Robert Lewandowski scored his second consecutive home hat-trick in the Bundesliga as 10-man Bayern Munich dominated Stuttgart 4-0, extending their lead at the top to four points. The Polish striker, who netted three times against Borussia Dortmund in his last league appearance at the Allianz Arena, needed just 39 minutes to replicate that performance here.

Serge Gnabry also found the net in a commanding first half, as Hansi Flick's side overcame the early dismissal of Alphonso Davies to secure a resounding victory. Davies was sent off after VAR upgraded his yellow card to a red for a studs-up challenge on Wataru Endo.

After weathering an early storm, Bayern took the lead through Lewandowski, who moved into second place on the Bundesliga's all-time top scorer list by converting Gnabry's low cross for his 269th goal in the competition.

- Ten men
- Four goals
- Three points
- Clean sheet
- Job well done

#FCBVfB 4-0 pic.twitter.com/fCxqUFC8a5 — FC Bayern English (@FCBayernEN) March 20, 2021

Gnabry then turned from provider to scorer, capitalizing on a slick exchange between Thomas Muller and Leroy Sane to finish a superb team goal. A minute later, Lewandowski's powerful header from Muller's right-wing cross put Bayern three goals ahead with less than a quarter of the game played. The prolific Pole completed his hat-trick just before halftime, seizing the ball inside the box and firing a left-footed shot into the bottom right corner, making it three goals from three shots.

Bayern's number nine should have added a fourth just past the hour mark but uncharacteristically misfired after being set up by Benjamin Pavard's low cross. However, that miss was inconsequential as the champions comfortably saw out their victory.

**What does it mean? History beckons for Lewandowski**

Having already scored more Bundesliga hat-tricks than any other player, Lewandowski added a 13th here, extending his lead over Mario Gomez (10) to three. The Pole now has 35 league goals this season and is likely aiming to break Gerd Muller's record of 40 goals in a single Bundesliga campaign, with eight games remaining. In fact, 'Der Bomber's' all-time scoring record of 365 goals doesn't seem out of reach for Lewandowski, who, at 32, still has several years at the top level.

**Lewa stars for Bayern**

Bayern faced challenges even before losing Davies, but the game's complexion changed entirely when Lewandowski scored his first goal in spectacular fashion. The fact that the Polish international completed his hat-trick with just three shots speaks volumes about his quality in front of goal.

**Davies errs again**

Were it not for Lewandowski's brilliance, Davies' reckless early challenge could have made for a difficult afternoon for his teammates.

Here's a restructured and improved version of the text, focusing on logical flow and clear argumentation against the use of facial action coding systems in classrooms:

The implementation of facial action coding systems in classrooms raises significant concerns regarding their reliability, security, and cost-effectiveness. While these systems claim to analyze students' emotional expressions, several critical issues make them unsuitable for educational environments.

First, the fundamental reliability of facial action coding systems is questionable. Though the technology claims to distinguish between genuine and fake smiles by analyzing muscle movements—such as the orbicularis muscle creating crow's feet around the eyes versus the zygomatic major and risorius muscles creating artificial smiles—various factors can compromise its accuracy. For instance, students wearing makeup or those with facial muscle conditions may generate inaccurate readings, leading to unreliable data.

Security and privacy present another major concern. The system's constant monitoring of students' faces creates an invasive learning environment. More worryingly, the technology's response to perceived positive reactions (such as automatically displaying more content when it detects happiness) could lead to unwanted pop-ups and potential security vulnerabilities. This automated response system could expose school computers to viruses or create opportunities for unauthorized access to surveillance footage.

Finally, the financial burden of implementing and maintaining these systems is substantial. Schools already struggling with limited resources would face difficult choices between funding essential programs and investing in this technology. When technical issues arise, schools might need to cut valuable extracurricular activities or educational programs to cover repair costs. This creates an equity issue, as some schools may be able to afford the system while others cannot, potentially leading to educational disparities.

Given these concerns about reliability, security, and cost, implementing facial action coding systems in classrooms appears imprudent. The unofficial nature of the technology, combined with its potential risks and financial implications, suggests that schools should explore more established and cost-effective methods for understanding and supporting student engagement.

# Introduction and Problem Statement

In the context of autonomous navigation, an active localization update [1], [2] refers to an action which provides the agent with its true state information, from sensor data, within the environment it is operating in. Every instance of actively localizing is a double-edged sword - it helps the agent get better state estimates using sensory data at the cost of depletion of limited resources [5] or increased risk of detection in sensitive applications [6].

Addressing trajectory tracking within environments characterized by a limited number of active localization updates and partial observability presents a critical challenge in the development of autonomous systems [3]. Such constraints are not merely technical limitations but are often necessitated by the operational environment itself [4]. The traditional paradigms of trajectory tracking, heavily reliant on uninterrupted data flows for state estimation and control [7] - [9], are ill-equipped to handle such scenarios.

# Current Approaches and Their Limitations

## Learning-Based Methods
The advent of learning-based methods [10] - [12] has introduced significant advancements in autonomous trajectory tracking. However, these approaches often grapple with the complexities of large state and action spaces [13], requiring substantial training and continuous dependency on true state data. Hence limited number of active localization updates and partial observability become a bottleneck in scenarios where the availability of such sensory data is heavily restricted [14].

## Multi-Agent Systems and Deep Reinforcement Learning
Recent studies have explored deep reinforcement learning for optimal communication strategies in multi-agent systems [15], [16]. A common limitation among these works is that they presuppose full observability of the agent's own state and partial observability of the other agents. Hence, the communication action is only used to estimate the states of other agents and not for localizing the agent itself.

## POMDP-Based Approaches
Some studies have tackled the issue of the agent's own state's partial observability by framing the trajectory tracking problem as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP).

I cowered behind a tree, watching. My legs had given out, but a low-hanging branch held me up, its strength greater than my own. A grisly orchestra of death reached out to me—not with song, but with screams. The dying and soon-to-be dead howled and hollered, begging for reprieve from the night. Their wish: to never see the sun rise again.

Muffled yet piercing pops echoed off the mall's facade. SEARS apparently had a sale on life: buy none, get one shot to the head for free.

I turned to the inferno. JC Penney blazed like a bonfire, its storefront glass melting as heat burst the fluorescent bulbs from their signage. Mannequins flickered into bright torches, only to burn out in seconds. Flames shot skyward in otherworldly colors—light green, purple, and pink—against the pitch-black sky.

I wrenched my gaze back to the two-man death squad, praying they hadn't spotted me. Their muzzled pops continued. I watched them reload and carry on.

Pop. Pop. Pop pop.

Brains, blood, and bodily fluids stained the parking lot. A slight breeze wafted the stench my way, and I retched, struggling to stay quiet. When I wiped my eyes, I noticed something new: JC Penney now sported a shiny, cylindrical chimney. It extended thirty feet above the collapsed roof—less like a missile, more like a ship.

A rectangular portal, three feet wide by eight feet tall, gaped at the cylinder's end, well above the cratered ceiling. A narrow tube snaked from the craft down into the SEARS store forty feet away.

"What the shit *is* this?"

I shifted my attention back to the executioners. They'd finished with the civilians near the mall and began sweeping the perimeter. I was about to call out when I noticed a bright red dot on my right thigh.

"Don't shoot! Holy fuck, don't shoot!" I leaped from behind the tree, hands raised, expecting to be gunned down. "I wasn't in the mall. I wasn't in there."

Glancing down, I watched the red dot climb my thigh to my belly, where two additional marks joined it. These weren't dots, though—they formed a symbol like / • \.  It crept up to my chest.

"Get down!" One of the killers stared at me, palm down, arm waving. "Get the fuck dow—"

I saw it before I heard it: a bright red orb materialized in the parking lot, then shot toward me with impossible speed. A split second later came an electrical crackle that shattered the night.

The ball struck my chest, exploding into a wet rainbow. Pale blue light ricocheted in tendrils of evaporating fluid. Yellow and green light diffused around my ribs, morphing into fingers that seemed to caress me into submission. But the red—the red splashed into a ring, one drop launching away, pulsing outward before stopping six feet away.

"Get down!" came the muffled cry. I couldn't see the killers; my eyes locked on that droplet. "Torch him, he's been taken."

I was so transfixed by the red drop that I didn't notice its twin falling from my forehead. Whatever had crawled from that cylinder had nearly snared me in an inescapable net.

The killers in the White Sands Mall parking lot knew what to do. The killers were the saviors.

# Introduction and Background

For most constant-coefficient partial differential equations (PDEs) in classical mathematical physics, exact forms of the solution operator (Green's function) are well-known. These are often used to transform boundary value problems into boundary integral equations, which are preferred for numerical solutions due to their conditioning properties and ability to handle complex geometries. Recent advances in hierarchical linear algebra, fast multipole methods, quadrature for singular functions, and computational geometry have made high-order accurate solutions via integral equations increasingly common.

However, for non-constant-coefficient PDEs, the analytical and numerical machinery is limited due to the lack of known Green's functions. While most numerical approaches use direct discretization through finite elements or finite difference schemes, approximate Green's functions (parametrix) can sometimes transform these PDEs into integral equations.

# Surface PDEs and Their Applications

## Definition and Basic Forms

Surface PDEs extend planar problems to smooth closed surfaces embedded in R³. A general elliptic PDE on a surface Γ takes the form:

∇ Γ • a∇ Γ u + b • ∇ Γ u + cu = f (1.1)

where u is the unknown function, f is known, a is smooth and positive, b is a continuous tangential vector field, and c is a continuous function.

## Important Special Cases

1. The Laplace-Beltrami problem:
   ∆ Γ u := ∇ Γ • ∇ Γ u = f (1.2)

2. The Helmholtz-Beltrami problem:
   ∆ Γ + k² u = f (1.3)

## Applications

The Laplace-Beltrami problem appears in:
- Computer graphics (interpolation and shape analysis)
- Plasma physics
- Vesicle deformation in biological flows
- Surface diffusion
- Computational geometry
- Computer vision
- Electromagnetics

# Existing Numerical Methods

## Direct Discretization Methods
- Finite element methods
- Virtual element method
- Differencing methods
- Pseudospectral methods
- Hierarchical Poincaré-Steklov methods

## Alternative Approaches
- Level set methods
- Closest point methods

# Proposed Parametrix-Based Solution

This paper presents a parametrix for equation (1.1) to convert it into an integral equation. The approach offers several advantages:

1. Uses only a single integral operator with less singular kernels
2. Applies to various equations on any smooth surface
3. Enables solutions for surface boundary value problems

# Paper Structure

The remainder of the paper covers:
1. Parametrix definitions and surface differential operators
2. Laplace-Beltrami problem solution
3. General case analysis (equation 1.1)
4. Surface elliptic boundary value problems
5. Integral equation discretization
6. Numerical experiments
7. Conclusions and future extensions

This restructuring provides a clearer progression from basic concepts to specific applications and solutions, while maintaining the technical depth of the original text.

# Code Syntax Highlighting: A Neural Network-Based Approach

## 1. Introduction and Context

Today, software developers heavily rely on online web applications for various source code manipulation tasks. These include:
- Repository hosting services (GitLab, BitBucket) for version control, DevOps, code reviews, and CI/CD
- Q&A platforms like StackOverflow for code-related queries
- Knowledge bases and collaborative tools

In these contexts, code syntax highlighting (SH) plays a crucial role in boosting productivity. SH is a form of secondary notation where text portions are displayed in different colors based on language features.

## 2. Current Challenges

### 2.1 Technical Challenges
1. **Grammatical Validity**: Online code snippets often lack complete grammatical correctness due to:
   - Incomplete code fragments in discussions
   - Code review snippets
   - Chat messages
   
2. **Performance Constraints**: 
   - SH must occur "on-the-fly" with minimal delay
   - Traditional parsing approaches are often too slow
   - User experience is directly impacted by highlighting speed

### 2.2 Implementation Limitations
Current approaches face several limitations:
- Brute-force (BF) methods using ASTs are computationally expensive
- Regular expression-based solutions offer limited grammatical coverage
- Manual regex design is error-prone and requires extensive testing

## 3. Proposed Solution

This paper introduces a novel approach using lightweight Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) to encode highlighting behaviors. Key features:

1. **Training Process**:
   - Uses BF approach to compile initial highlighting assignments
   - Trains RNN to map token sequences to highlighting classes
   - One-time training produces reusable model

2. **Implementation Benefits**:
   - Simple to implement
   - Deterministic and reusable
   - Low-effort process for customization
   - High grammatical coverage
   - Accurate highlighting
   - Flexible input handling

## 4. Experimental Validation

The approach was tested across:
- Four types of grammatical coverages
- Three programming languages (Java, Kotlin, Python)
- Comparison with popular tools like Pygments
- Performance metrics for both correct and incorrect code

## 5. Key Contributions

1. SH benchmarking dataset for Java, Kotlin, and Python
2. Neural Network-based SH design with near-perfect accuracy
3. Comparative analysis with current practices
4. Performance evaluation for incomplete code
5. Open-source implementation and datasets

## 6. Paper Structure

# The Promise of Driverless Cars

Driverless cars represent an exciting advancement in transportation technology, and I strongly support their development. These autonomous vehicles offer numerous benefits, from enhancing safety to providing convenient transportation solutions.

One of the most compelling advantages of driverless cars is their potential to reduce drunk driving incidents. Instead of risking lives by getting behind the wheel after consuming alcohol, people can rely on their autonomous vehicles to transport them safely home. Advanced sensor technology could even be implemented to detect a driver's blood alcohol level, preventing manual operation when necessary.

Fatigue-related accidents could also become a thing of the past. For those exhausted after a long workday or those who struggle with night vision, autonomous vehicles offer a reliable alternative to dangerous drowsy driving. Whether you're returning from a late shift or finishing a demanding grocery shopping trip, your driverless car can ensure a safe journey home.

Furthermore, driverless cars present a smart economic investment for our society. As noted in the source material, these vehicles are projected to use "half the fuel of today's taxis while offering far more flexibility than a bus." This efficiency could revolutionize our transportation infrastructure, providing a cost-effective alternative to traditional taxi services. Consider the financial impact: rather than spending thousands annually on taxi fares, individuals could invest in autonomous vehicles that offer both convenience and long-term savings.

The environmental benefits are equally noteworthy, as reduced fuel consumption contributes to a smaller carbon footprint. This technology could transform not only our country's transportation system but potentially influence global mobility solutions.

In conclusion, the advent of driverless cars represents a significant step forward in transportation technology. Their potential to enhance safety, reduce accidents, and offer economic benefits makes them a welcome innovation for our future.

My support clinked together as I shifted, supporting my weight with my legs. I hissed at a stabbing pain in my neck, and a wet feeling I couldn't remove. I shifted again and the stabbing returned, this time a little blood dropped onto my chest.

I slumped back against the supports. The light behind my eyes dimmed from red to black. When I chose to open them I was confronted with nothing but a concrete wall.

My eyes focused on the man stood in front of me, his movements painfully slow as he reached forwards and removed the metal collar.

The Face on Mars has captivated public imagination for decades, though many dismiss the idea of its alien origins. More likely, this intriguing formation resulted from natural processes such as storms or meteor impacts. NASA prioritized photographing this distinctive rock formation, and scientists generally concluded it was simply another Martian mesa, a common geological feature in the Cydonia region.

When NASA first released the image, they labeled it simply as a "huge rock formation." Scientists noted that the face-like appearance resulted from shadows creating the illusion of eyes, nose, and mouth. An opportunistic author later recognized the formation's potential to generate public interest in Mars exploration.

The Face quickly became a worldwide cultural phenomenon, appearing in Hollywood films, books, magazines, radio talk shows, and tabloid headlines. Some interpreted it as potential evidence of extraterrestrial life on Mars, leading to speculation about NASA withholding information. Others suggested that supporters of NASA's budget might welcome the possibility of an ancient Martian civilization.

On April 8, 2001, the Mars Global Surveyor captured new, detailed images of the formation. As Jim Garvin explained, "We had to roll the spacecraft 25 degrees to center the Face in the field of view." Malin's team obtained high-resolution photographs using the camera's maximum capabilities. The 2001 images achieved remarkable clarity, with each pixel representing 1.56 meters—a dramatic improvement from the 1976 Viking photos' 43 meters per pixel.

While the true nature of the Face on Mars remains a subject of debate, scientists have conducted extensive research to understand its origins. Most experts consider it a Martian butte or mesa, similar to geological formations found on Earth. Though some still speculate about artificial origins, the scientific consensus leans toward natural geological processes. While both possibilities persist in public discourse, definitive proof remains elusive.

Large Language Models (LLMs) have made remarkable strides in recent years, demonstrating significant performance improvements across various benchmarks, including SuperGLUE (Wang et al., 2019), MMLU (Hendrycks et al., 2021b), and professional examinations like the U.S. bar exam (Katz et al., 2023). However, researchers have yet to fully understand the relationship between domain-specific training and within-domain evaluation. Our work investigates how training on specialized legal corpora impacts performance across the most comprehensive set of legal-domain evaluation benchmarks known to date. We examine models' capabilities in question-answering, classification, judgment formation, information extraction, and higher-order cognitive tasks (collectively termed "reasoning") within this specialized domain, contrasting with broad-domain benchmarking approaches. Our findings reveal that while domain-specific pretraining and instruction tuning generally enhance performance, these improvements vary significantly across tasks, training regimes, model sizes, and other factors.

Despite their superior performance on LegalBench (77.3 for GPT-4 compared to 60.1 for Flan-T5 XXL), large closed models still exhibit substantial hallucination when processing legal texts (Dahl et al., 2024). The legal sector's stringent requirements for trust and data protection often necessitate on-premise deployments, precluding the use of public models like Claude or GPT-4. This limitation underscores the importance of developing robust open models. Our research explores performance enhancement strategies through in-domain instruction tuning and continued pretraining on Flan-T5, currently the leading open model for LegalBench in both the 3B and 11B parameter ranges.

Our methodology employs MultiLegalPile (Niklaus et al., 2023b), a comprehensive 689GB multilingual legal corpus, for continued pretraining. To address the absence of legal reasoning instruction datasets, we developed LawInstruct, encompassing 24 languages across 17 jurisdictions on four continents. This dataset comprises 12M training examples covering legal domain tasks such as QA, entailment, summarization, and information extraction, each formatted with custom instructions and corresponding outputs. Our fine-tuning experiments on LegalBench (Guha et al., 2023) and MMLU (Hendrycks et al., 2021a) demonstrate significant improvements: Flan-T5 XL models achieved a balanced accuracy of 58.1 on LegalBench, an 8-point (16%) improvement over baseline. More remarkably, the Small model showed a 9.6-point (38.1%) improvement, extending to 14 points (55.4%) with additional pretraining.

Our research offers four primary contributions:
1. Creation of the first comprehensive legal instruction dataset, consolidating and standardizing instructions for 58 high-quality annotated datasets across diverse legal tasks
2. Achievement of new state-of-the-art results on LegalBench across all tested parameter ranges through continued pretraining and instruction tuning of T5, mT5, and Flan-T5 models
3. Extensive ablation studies across various dataset configurations, yielding novel insights into domain adaptation
4. Public release of the permissively-licensed portion of the curated dataset on the Hugging Face Hub¹, along with the dataset creation code² and guidance for accessing restricted data portions requiring special agreements

This defensive mindset cost me friendships. At eight, I stormed out of a sleepover because another girl wanted to play with makeup. My last memory was of a little redheaded girl crying because of my cruelty. After that, our paths rarely crossed outside of school.

Everything shifted when Samantha moved into our cul-de-sac. A year older than me, she seemed to share my worldview. Her brown hair was cropped boyishly short, and for two years, I only saw her in jeans and sneakers. Recognizing a kindred spirit, she immediately claimed me as her best friend.

Samantha spent weekends at her father's farm, and one day, she invited me along. We found endless mischief there - crawling through seemingly endless bramble bushes, pilfering Farmer McPhearson's blueberries, and catching fireflies in jars. **The Promise and Perils of Autonomous Vehicles**

Driverless cars represent a significant advancement in technology, but serious questions remain about whether we're ready to entrust our lives to computer-controlled vehicles. While these vehicles might help reduce some road dangers, the risk of technological malfunction poses a critical concern.

The implementation challenges are substantial. The infrastructure requirements alone present a major hurdle, as existing roads would need massive, costly upgrades to accommodate autonomous vehicles. Additionally, the vehicles themselves would be significantly more expensive to manufacture than traditional cars. The legal framework also remains unclear: who bears responsibility when technology fails—the driver or the manufacturer? These questions must be resolved before widespread adoption becomes feasible.

While companies like Tesla project optimistic timelines—such as their 2016 goal for 90% autopilot capability—the reality is more complex. New technology invariably experiences glitches and malfunctions during early adoption. This risk becomes particularly concerning when considering scenarios like impaired individuals attempting to control autonomous vehicles, potentially compromising the safety systems.

The reliability of autonomous vehicles as public transportation also raises concerns. Scheduling dependencies could lead to increased tardiness, and the technology's vulnerability to malfunctions could strand passengers. When weighing the potential benefits against the substantial costs—both financial and in terms of public safety—the current state of driverless technology appears to present more risks than rewards.

In conclusion, while autonomous vehicles showcase impressive technological advancement, the combination of high costs, unresolved legal issues, safety concerns, and infrastructure requirements suggests that widespread implementation remains premature. The stakes are simply too high when human lives are involved to rush this technology to market without resolving these fundamental challenges.

This more pressing challenge deserves our attention and investment, rather than spending vast resources on self-driving technology.

Las comunidades autónomas de Castilla y León, Aragón y Castilla-La Mancha celebraron hoy una reunión de trabajo para analizar la implementación de ayudas destinadas a reducir los costes laborales de las empresas en las provincias de Soria, Teruel y Cuenca.

Participaron en el encuentro el consejero de Economía y Hacienda de la Junta de Castilla y León, Carlos Fernández Carriedo; la consejera de Presidencia y Relaciones Institucionales del Gobierno de Aragón, Mayte Pérez; y el vicepresidente de la Junta de Castilla-La Mancha, José Luis Martínez Guijarro, según informó la Junta de Castilla y León mediante comunicado oficial a Ical.

Durante la reunión, realizada por videoconferencia, se examinó un informe técnico sobre la aplicación de estos beneficios. El documento establece que las ayudas se materialicen como una reducción en la cotización empresarial por contingencias comunes en el Régimen General de la Seguridad Social. Estos beneficios se aplicarían a todas las empresas que desarrollen actividad económica en las zonas asistidas, independientemente de su tamaño y forma jurídica, abarcando todas las modalidades de contratos laborales. Las ayudas tendrían carácter indefinido mientras la empresa mantenga su actividad y sean compatibles con la normativa europea.

Las ayudas de funcionamiento de finalidad regional están destinadas a reducir los gastos corrientes empresariales, incluyendo los costes de personal. Según el artículo 15.3 del RGEC, estas bonificaciones deben prevenir o reducir la despoblación, siempre que los beneficiarios mantengan su actividad económica en la zona correspondiente. El importe anual de las ayudas por beneficiario, considerando todos los regímenes de ayudas de funcionamiento, no podrá superar el 20 por ciento de sus costes laborales anuales en la zona en cuestión.

Se define como coste salarial el importe total que debe abonar el beneficiario, incluyendo salarios brutos y cotizaciones obligatorias, como la seguridad social y gastos por cuidados infantil y parental durante un período determinado.

La implementación más eficiente de estas ayudas de funcionamiento sobre costes de personal se realizaría mediante beneficios en las cotizaciones a la Seguridad Social, específicamente en las aportaciones empresariales a las cuotas por contingencias comunes en el Régimen General, excluyendo las contingencias por accidente laboral, enfermedad profesional y cuotas de recaudación conjunta.

El sistema más práctico consiste en aplicar bonificaciones o reducciones porcentuales, estableciendo un tipo de cotización sobre las bases de cotización por contingencias comunes inferior al tipo general, siguiendo el modelo implementado en Noruega.

En 2019, la Comisión Europea evaluó las Directrices de la Unión Europea sobre Ayudas Estatales de Finalidad Regional (DAFR). Posteriormente, en julio de 2020, realizó una consulta pública sobre el proyecto de texto, previa a la aprobación de las Directrices sobre ayudas regionales revisadas para el período 2022-2027.

Las tres comunidades autónomas acordaron presentar una respuesta conjunta a dicha consulta, solicitando que las futuras DAFR y el Reglamento General de Exención por Categorías (RGEC) equipararan el régimen jurídico de las "zonas poco pobladas" con el de las "zonas de muy baja densidad de población", unificando ambas categorías y permitiendo la concesión de ayudas al funcionamiento en ambos casos.

Tras la evaluación, la Comisión Europea aprobó una revisión de las DAFR, estableciendo las normas para que los Estados miembros otorguen ayudas estatales a empresas, fomentando el desarrollo económico en zonas desfavorecidas de la UE.

# Sleep Duration Linked to Cognitive Decline in Older Adults, New Study Finds

A groundbreaking study from Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis has revealed that older adults who sleep either too little or too much experience greater cognitive decline compared to those who maintain moderate sleep patterns. This relationship persists even when accounting for early Alzheimer's disease effects, according to findings published in the journal 'Brain'.

## Untangling Sleep and Alzheimer's

Researchers have long struggled to differentiate between the cognitive impacts of poor sleep and Alzheimer's disease. This study provides crucial insights by:

- Tracking cognitive function in older adults over several years
- Analyzing Alzheimer's-related protein levels
- Measuring brain activity during sleep

"Understanding the relationship between sleep patterns and Alzheimer's disease progression is essential for developing effective interventions," explains lead author Brendan Lucey, MD, associate professor of neurology and director of the Washington University Sleep Medicine Center.

## Key Findings

The research revealed several significant insights:

1. A "sweet spot" for sleep duration exists where cognitive performance remains stable
2. Both shorter (<4.5 hours) and longer (>6.5 hours) sleep durations correlate with cognitive decline
3. This U-shaped relationship holds true for both REM and non-REM sleep phases
4. The correlation persists even after adjusting for factors like age, sex, and genetic predisposition

## Methodology

The study examined:
- 100 participants (average age 75)
- 4.5-year average monitoring period
- EEG sleep monitoring for 4-6 nights
- Cerebrospinal fluid analysis for Alzheimer's proteins
- Regular cognitive assessments

## Clinical Implications

Dr. Beau M. Ances, Professor of Neurology at Barnes-Jewish Hospital, emphasizes the importance of addressing sleep issues in patients with cognitive complaints. "Sleep quality is potentially modifiable," he notes, "and improving sleep patterns may lead to cognitive benefits."

The researchers stress that individual sleep needs vary, and people who feel well-rested should maintain their current sleep patterns. However, those experiencing sleep problems should seek treatment, as addressing sleep issues may help maintain cognitive function as they age.

This research represents a significant step forward in understanding the complex relationship between sleep patterns, cognitive decline, and Alzheimer's disease, offering new possibilities for intervention and treatment strategies.

# The Challenge of Long Video Temporal Grounding

## Introduction

The exponential growth in online video content has created an urgent need for efficient content retrieval systems. When users search through long videos (20-120 minutes), they often need to locate specific moments. While existing solutions [40, 52, 54] work well for short videos (5-30 seconds), they struggle with longer content, resulting in slower retrieval times and diminished result quality [39, 53]. This challenge, known as Long Video Temporal Grounding (LVTG) [13, 39], stems from the inherent difficulty of pinpointing brief moments within extended video content based on text queries.

## RGNet: A Novel Approach

![Overview of RGNet](fig1.png)
*Figure 1: RGNet Architecture Overview - The system predicts moment boundaries in hour-long videos based on textual queries. The RG-Encoder maps video and text features to a joint space, retrieving relevant clip features. A grounding decoder then processes these features to predict the moment's start and end times. The encoder operates simultaneously across multiple granularity levels (clip and frame) for an end-to-end solution.*

### Current Limitations

Traditional approaches [15, 36] to LVTG typically employ a two-step process: first dividing the video into shorter clips and retrieving the most relevant one, then applying a grounding network to predict the specific moment. However, this approach has a critical flaw - the grounding network cannot compensate for errors in the initial clip retrieval phase. Our empirical evaluation in Section 5.3 confirms that clip retrieval is the primary bottleneck in performance.

Existing methods separate clip retrieval from their grounding network (Figure 2), typically employing text-video retrieval techniques [12, 22, 28]. However, while video retrieval excels at high-level understanding (e.g., "A movie about a family surviving in a farmhouse"), LVTG requires fine-grained event comprehension (e.g., "Find the moment when the mum hangs up laundry outside the farmhouse"). This mismatch makes traditional video retrieval models suboptimal for precise moment localization.

### The RGNet Solution

We propose RGNet, a unified clip Retrieval and Grounding Network (Figure 1), to address these limitations. By combining clip selection and grounding in a single network, we enable end-to-end training of both stages. This unified approach enhances the retrieval module's fine-grained event understanding through direct optimization with moment annotations, while the grounding network benefits from improved multimodal features.

#### Key Innovations

1. **RG-Encoder**: A novel transformer encoder that enables integrated clip retrieval and grounding
2. **Sparse-Attention Mechanism**: Allows the retrieval module to focus on specific video events
3. **Intra-Clip Attention Loss**: Guides sparse attention toward event-aligned video frames
4. **Negative Clip Mining**: Simulates long-video retrieval during training

## Contributions

1. Systematic analysis of LVTG methods, identifying disjoint retrieval as the primary performance bottleneck
2. Introduction of RGNet, integrating clip retrieval with grounding through multi-level modeling
3. Development of sparse attention and negative clip-mining strategies for improved event understanding
4.

Julia Lovell, historienne britannique, nous livre une analyse approfondie de la guerre menée contre la Chine dans les années 1830-1840 - un conflit déclenché sous couvert du libre-échange pour maintenir le commerce de l'opium.

Ninguna sociedad que se defina como democrática puede serlo si carece de un Estado de leyes. El derecho tiene que imperar por encima de los deseos personales de gobernantes y juzgadores. En caso contrario, se corre el riesgo de que prive la barbarie. México no puede ser una excepción en esta realidad.

En este sentido, las noticias no son buenas para nuestro país. Hace apenas unos días, el World Justice Project presentó su Índice de Estado de Derecho 2017–2018, para medir la observancia del mismo en 113 países de todo el mundo, en ocho aspectos: restricciones a las facultades del gobierno, ausencia de corrupción, gobierno abierto, derechos fundamentales, orden y seguridad, aplicación de las leyes, justicia civil y justicia criminal.

Desde la publicación del último Índice, en octubre de 2016, la mayoría de los países estudiados disminuyeron puntos en las áreas de derechos humanos, controles de los poderes del gobierno, y justicia civil y penal. El mayor descenso se observó en los derechos fundamentales, que mide la ausencia de discriminación, el derecho a la vida y la seguridad, el debido proceso, la libertad de expresión y religión, el derecho a la privacidad, la libertad de asociación y los derechos laborales. El segundo mayor descenso se observó en las restricciones a los poderes del gobierno, que determina el grado en que los gobernantes están sujetos a la ley.

Los tres países mejor evaluados en el mencionado Índice fueron, nuevamente, Dinamarca (1), Noruega (2) y Finlandia (3); los peores evaluados fueron, otra vez, Afganistán (111), Camboya (112) y Venezuela (113), igual que en 2016. En la región latinoamericana, el lugar más destacado lo ocuparon: Uruguay (22), Costa Rica (24), Chile (27), Argentina (46), Brasil (52), Perú (60), Panamá (61), Colombia (72), El Salvador (79), Belice (81) y Ecuador (85).

México (92) solo supera en la materia a Guatemala (96), Nicaragua (99), Honduras (103), Bolivia (106) y Venezuela, que nuevamente tuvo el puntaje más bajo entre los 113 países analizados. Nuestro país apenas alcanza un puntaje de 0.45 de calificación, es decir menos de la mitad, en observancia del Estado de derecho. Esto significa que está reprobado en la materia. Pero no solo eso: las cifras indican que de 2016 a la fecha bajó cuatro lugares en el Índice, una cifra que refleja el constante deterioro que sufre nuestro país en este campo.

Foundation models, trained on vast and diverse datasets, have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across various tasks and are revolutionizing artificial intelligence. These models exhibit extraordinary zero-shot and few-shot generalization abilities, enabling significant progress across numerous downstream tasks. Unlike traditional methods that require training task-specific models from scratch, the "pre-training then fine-tuning" paradigm has proven particularly effective in computer vision. The Segment Anything Model (SAM), pre-trained on 1 billion masks across 11 million natural images, has emerged as a groundbreaking visual foundation model for prompt-driven image segmentation, capable of generating precise object binary masks through its impressive zero-shot capabilities.

Medical image segmentation, a crucial branch of image segmentation, has been dominated by deep learning methods in recent years. However, existing deep learning models are often highly specialized, with strong inductive biases that limit their versatility. This raises an important question: Can SAM revolutionize medical image segmentation? More specifically, can SAM achieve high performance in medical image segmentation through proper fine-tuning, building upon its strong zero-shot capabilities in natural image segmentation?

To address these questions, several intrinsic challenges must first be overcome. The primary limitation is SAM's inability to predict semantic labels for generated binary masks, as it only produces a single binary mask per prompt without semantic associations. Medical images typically involve multiple labels, each carrying specific semantic information. Additionally, SAM requires precise user prompts to segment target regions, and its direct application to medical image segmentation tasks sometimes yields suboptimal results, even with appropriate prompts. Therefore, the challenge lies in refining the fine-tuning process to adapt SAM from natural to medical image segmentation.

Given that it's unrealistic to expect all users to possess the medical knowledge necessary for providing accurate prompts, developing a prompt-free architecture becomes crucial. The image encoder in SAM employs a Vision Transformer (ViT) pre-trained with a masked auto-encoder as its backbone, which extracts essential features through a series of transformer blocks. To address the prompt-free requirement, we introduce a prompt generator that leverages multiple levels of feature maps from the image encoder to generate auxiliary binary masks and bounding boxes as prompts, eliminating the need for manual input.

三大领头企业——贝佐斯的蓝色起源(Blue Origin)、布兰森爵士的维珍银河(Virgin Galactic)和马斯克的SpaceX——各自采取了不同的发展路径。

今年7月，布兰森搭乘维珍银河成功飞上太空，比贝佐斯与蓝色起源早了9天。当时两家公司看似势均力敌。然而三个月后，形势已大不相同：蓝色起源已完成第二次载人飞行，搭载了2名付费客户和特别来宾沙特纳；而维珍银河则宣布需要8到10个月时间改进飞行器，推迟了原定的太空飞行测试，并确认2022年底前无法开始商业服务。

与此同时，SpaceX在9月成功完成了Inspiration4任务，将4名非专业太空人送入轨道。SpaceX的服务与其他两家有显著区别：乘客不仅飞到更远的轨道，还能在太空停留3天，而不是仅仅几分钟。当然，价格也相应更高：按照NASA每位太空人5500万元的标准计算，SpaceX的旅程约需2亿元。相比之下，维珍银河的价格为20万至45万元，而蓝色起源则未公开票价。

# Coastal Alabama Town Closes Beaches Amid Coronavirus Concerns

*GULF SHORES, Ala. (AP)* — Alabama's largest coastal city announced Thursday it would close its public beaches after spring break crowds continued to ignore social distancing guidelines aimed at preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus.

Gulf Shores Mayor Robert Craft said the tourist-dependent city would close public beaches from Friday through April 6 to discourage large gatherings of students. "This will be a threat to our livelihood, but it's also a threat to lives," Craft emphasized. Private beaches adjacent to condominiums and beach houses will remain accessible.

In the neighboring community of Orange Beach, Mayor Tony Kennon noted an unprecedented surge in spring break visitors, partially attributed to Florida's stricter measures, which included closing restaurants and nightclubs while many Alabama establishments remained operational.

"We have more spring breakers right now in this town than we've had in the last three years," Kennon reported.

While local officials have requested state intervention to restrict beach access, Governor Kay Ivey has yet to announce any measures. Several prominent businesses, including the Flora-Bama Lounge and LuLu's restaurant in Gulf Shores, have voluntarily suspended operations, though others continue to operate.

State health officials reported 68 confirmed COVID-19 cases in Alabama as of Thursday, marking a 17-case increase from the previous day, affecting 14 of the state's 67 counties. Jefferson County, the state's most populous region, recorded the highest number of cases. Baldwin County, home to Gulf Shores and Orange Beach, confirmed one case.

The Alabama Nursing Home Association disclosed two confirmed cases within state nursing facilities—one resident and one staff member—though specific locations were not identified. Nursing homes statewide have already implemented visitor restrictions.

For most individuals, the virus causes mild to moderate symptoms, including fever and cough. However, older adults and those with underlying health conditions may experience more severe complications, including pneumonia. The majority of patients recover fully.

```markdown
The man wiped his brow and steadied his breathing. He observed the bodies to his left and the mangled remains to his right. Crawling towards a table where a broken corpse lay, he crept slowly to the window and pressed his face against the glass. At first, he savored the cool surface against his burning cheeks, but then he retreated slightly to observe the countryside, cherishing that millisecond of focus his sight would allow before his vista scrambled and tore from vision.

The train was building speed. The once-ambling journey had become chaotic—a torment of metal-on-metal, screeching and howling and tearing through the pastoral calm outside. He knew it now: time was ebbing away as the skyline of an unfamiliar city grew larger and more bustling, unknowing of what approached. A body on the floor stirred and groaned slightly. The man removed himself from the window and shot that body dead again, and a certain stillness returned to the train cabin.

This man was mad—born of no solid belief and encouraged only by that voice in his head. He grinned at how that sweet old lady off 5th Street had helped carry the explosives to his truck. *Was that compassion?* the man thought.

"Nah," he said to the corpse as it rattled one long, final gasp. "Some men are just crazy."

The city was in full view now, framed only by the edges of a countryside where graffiti crept onto walls and wildlife dared not venture. Through a tunnel, mechanical-nothings flashed by—maybe a light or two, of varying colors, and a blurred sign here and there. It was time.

*Should I?* the man thought, his lip curling at the edge into something sinister. He didn't answer; it was rhetorical—it was *always* rhetorical. People—hundreds of them—waited for a train that would not stop. Timing now was key, and the man was cold, impeccable, efficient.

*Bang*.
```

# New Zealand's Influence on Irish Beer Culture

According to Paul McConville of The Irish News, Joe Schmidt's popularity in Ireland surpasses even the most decisive Russian election victories. Yet New Zealand's influence extends beyond rugby, making significant inroads into Ireland's craft beer scene.

The antipodean impact isn't limited to imported hops—Southern Hemisphere brewing expertise has also found its way to Irish shores. A prime example is Eight Degrees Brewing in Mitchelstown, County Cork. Founded by New Zealander Scott Baigent and Australian Cameron Wallace, the brewery has established itself as a pioneer in Ireland's craft beer landscape. Recently, they joined the growing trend of craft brewers transitioning to canned beverages.

As Irish brewers increasingly adopt canning technology—citing benefits like enhanced freshness and improved storage—Eight Degrees has embraced this evolution while celebrating its Kiwi roots. Their creation, Neon Velvet, exemplifies this fusion: a Kiwi and lime-infused Fruity Pale Ale (FPA). Packaged in striking 440ml cans at 5% ABV, this amber-colored brew presents with an intentional haziness and delivers vibrant fruity aromas when served at its optimal temperature of 8 degrees.

The beer's profile features juicy, fruit-forward flavors with subtle acidic notes. The brewers combine Citra and Amarillo hops during the brewing process, then dry-hop with New Zealand varieties to achieve a fresh, zesty character. The addition of oats and wheat to the malt bill creates a smooth, silky mouthfeel without overwhelming bitterness. The brewery's initial canning lineup also included their acclaimed Full Irish IPA and a single-hop Citra IPA.

Baigent, who transitioned from water engineering, partnered with Wallace to establish Eight Degrees Brewing in 2010, marking the beginning of their contribution to Ireland's evolving craft beer landscape.

*Source: Paul McConville, The Irish News, March 31, 2018*

# Birkenstock in Talks for CVC Capital Partners Takeover

The iconic German sandal maker Birkenstock is in advanced negotiations with private equity firm CVC Capital Partners for a potential takeover valued at more than 4 billion euros (S$6.38 billion) including debt, according to sources familiar with the matter.

## Historical Legacy and Brand Evolution

Founded in 1774 by cobbler Johann Adam Birkenstock in the German state of Hesse, the company's heritage has become a key selling point for consumers drawn to products with authentic history. While the brand's roots stretch back nearly 250 years, Birkenstock's signature sandals were first introduced in the 1960s.

The sandals made their U.S. debut in 1966 when Margot Fraser, discovering them during a German vacation, began importing them. The brand gained significant popularity in the 1990s and 2000s, boosted by celebrity endorsements from Kate Moss and Heidi Klum. This success has inspired luxury variants from high-end labels including Celine and Givenchy.

## Current Business Performance

Under the leadership of Co-Chief Executive Officers Markus Bensberg and Oliver Reichert since 2013, Birkenstock has expanded its product line to include belts, bags, and beds, with distribution in approximately 90 countries. The company's financial performance has been strong, with:

- 23.8 million pairs of shoes sold in FY2019
- Sales increase of 11% to 721.5 million euros
- Net income growth of 40% to 129 million euros

- Breitling SA, the Swiss watchmaker known for aviation-themed timepieces
- German beauty chain Douglas GmbH

  - MediaTek
  - Huawei

In response, Nvidia has pledged to maintain Arm's open business model.

## Timeline and Outlook

Negotiations between Nvidia and the UK government are ongoing, with no deal expected to conclude this year. The combination of hiring concerns, governmental scrutiny, and industry opposition presents significant challenges for the proposed takeover's success.

# Fractional Calculus and Modern Computational Methods: A Comprehensive Review

## Introduction

Fractional calculus (FC) [1], a specialized branch of mathematical analysis, extends traditional calculus by incorporating non-integer orders of differentiation and integration. Over the past four decades, FC has emerged as a powerful tool in modeling real-world phenomena, particularly in systems where nonlocality plays a crucial role. Its applications span diverse scientific disciplines, offering novel approaches to understanding complex real-world dynamics through empirical data analysis.

## Applications and Significance

In underwater sediment studies and biomedical applications, fractional derivative models have proven invaluable for understanding wave propagation and absorption mechanisms, particularly in materials like polymers [2]. A notable advancement includes the development of a Continuous Time Random Walk (CTRW) framework [3], which employs fractional calculus to optimize search strategies for targets with unknown locations.

Unlike traditional integer-order systems, fractional order systems exhibit long memory characteristics, enabling enhanced control methods and strategies [4]. The field has found applications in:
- Image processing [5]
- Differential equations (various types)
- Integral differential equations
- Partial differential equations (PDEs)
- Differential-algebraic equations (DAEs)
- Delay differential equations (DDEs)

## Delay Differential Equations and Their Applications

DDEs represent a distinct class of differential equations where solutions depend on previous time states. Their applications encompass:
- Biological systems
- Engineering
- Physics
- Economics and finance
- Chemical reactions
- Ecology
- Communication networks
- Weather and climate
- Medicine [7-9]

### Specialized Types of Delay Equations

Pantograph delay differential equations (PDDEs) introduce additional complexity by incorporating both forward and backward time delays. These equations have proven valuable in modeling:
- Pantograph control systems
- Cell growth [10]
- Population dynamics [11]
- Electric locomotive systems [12]

## Solution Methods and Computational Approaches

### Traditional Methods

The primary approaches for solving DDEs include:
1. Numerical methods
2. Analytical methods
3. Semi-analytical methods

Key analytical techniques include:
- Method of steps [16]
- Laplace transform techniques [17]
- Perturbation-iteration methods [18]

### Advanced Numerical Techniques

Modern numerical methods encompass:
- Finite difference methods [19]
- Spectral methods
- Finite element methods
- Meshless methods

## Machine Learning Applications

Machine learning has emerged as a powerful tool for solving differential equations, offering:
- Enhanced flexibility
- Improved accuracy
- Reduced computational costs
- Robust generalization

Notable implementations include:
- Artificial Neural Networks (ANN)
- Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs)
- Orthogonal function-based networks

## Proposed Methodology

This paper introduces:
1. A non-uniform discretization approach for Caputo-based fractional differential equations
2. Integration with Legendre Deep Neural Network (LDNN)
3. Solutions for various types of differential equations:
   - Pantograph delay differential equations
   - Nonlinear delay differential equations

# The Facial Action Coding System in Education: A Critical Analysis

The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) represents a significant advancement in science and technology, but its implementation in school computers warrants careful consideration. While this technology offers potential benefits in educational settings, it also presents notable challenges.

According to Nick D'Alto's article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," integrating FACS into school computers could help identify when students struggle with lessons and automatically adjust content to support their learning. Let's examine both the advantages and disadvantages of this technology.

## Benefits

The primary advantage of implementing FACS in educational computers lies in its ability to read students' facial expressions and determine their level of comprehension. This real-time feedback could enable dynamic lesson adjustments, potentially improving student understanding and learning outcomes.

## Challenges

### Limited Applicability
Not all schools rely heavily on digital learning. While some institutions embrace e-learning—where students complete coursework entirely on school-issued computers—many still primarily utilize traditional teaching methods. FACS would prove most beneficial in e-learning environments but might offer limited value in schools that primarily conduct face-to-face instruction.

### Financial Considerations
The implementation costs of FACS raise important questions:
- What is the system's cost?
- Can schools justify this additional expense?
- Is this investment necessary given that schools have functioned effectively without such technology?

Students already have various resources available, including teacher assistance and internet access, to help them understand challenging concepts.

# New Community Science Program Launches to Protect Ontario Waterways

The Sault's Invasive Species Centre has launched IsampleON, a new community science program aimed at protecting Ontario's waterways from invasive species this summer. The initiative will mobilize volunteers from more than 500 organizations across the province to help identify invasive species in Ontario's lakes.

"Volunteers will be collecting and analyzing water samples on lakes and shorelines," explained Rebecca Schroeder, Aquatic Invasive Species liaison. "They will then be sending them back to us where we analyze them for presence or absence of invasive mussel veligers." This proactive approach will help the Centre protect watersheds throughout the province.

The Federation of Ontario Cottagers' Association will coordinate the volunteer efforts. Terry Rees, the organization's executive director, emphasized the unique role of volunteers: "Each of them has got a unique opportunity to be eyes and ears on the water and look out for our environment."

While invasive mussels remain a concern across Ontario, the program will initially focus on 25 lakes from three watersheds. A key component of the initiative is raising public awareness, particularly among boaters who use multiple lakes.

"It means everyone who moves a boat from one waterbody to another has an opportunity to do their part to ensure they're not moving any water from one waterbody to another," Rees noted.

Hello, I'm Luke Bomberger, and I'd like to share my experience with the Seagoing Cowboys Program, which I joined when I was 18. It was a life-changing adventure, and I hope my story will inspire you to consider joining as well.

# Fonds européens : La fronde s'étend et l'Est se divise sur le Plan de relance

## Le conflit principal
La Hongrie et la Pologne, régulièrement accusées de ne pas respecter la séparation des pouvoirs, prennent en otage le budget et le plan de relance économique de l'Union européenne. L'adoption de ce plan requiert l'unanimité des 27 États membres. Ces deux pays rejettent l'introduction d'une clause inédite prévoyant des sanctions en cas de violation documentée de l'État de droit.

## Les enjeux financiers
En juillet, après quatre jours et quatre nuits de sommet marathon, les chefs d'État et de gouvernement s'étaient accordés sur une feuille de route comprenant :
- Un plan de relance de 750 milliards d'euros
- Un "cadre financier pluriannuel" (2021-2027) de plus de 1000 milliards d'euros

Pour la Hongrie, l'enjeu est considérable : les fonds européens représentaient en 2019 environ 4,48% de son produit national brut, l'un des taux les plus élevés parmi les pays de l'UE. Budapest devrait bénéficier de 16,7 milliards d'euros en subventions et crédits potentiels pour la prochaine période.

## La position des opposants
Viktor Orban, Premier ministre hongrois, affirme que l'Europe pourrait "utiliser des moyens financiers pour faire chanter les pays qui s'opposent à l'immigration". Il compare même l'UE à une nouvelle "Union soviétique" où les grands pays dicteraient la conduite aux autres. Cependant, il entrouvre une porte au compromis en réclamant des "critères objectifs" et la "possibilité d'un recours juridique".

La Slovénie, initialement neutre, a rejoint les opposants. Son Premier ministre Janez Jansa, proche d'Orban, soutient que "seule une instance judiciaire indépendante peut dire ce qu'est l'État de droit, pas une majorité politique".

## La division au sein de l'Est
Le conflit ne représente pas une simple opposition Est-Ouest. Plusieurs pays de l'Est affichent leur soutien à la clause sur l'État de droit :
- La Slovaquie et la République tchèque
- La Roumanie, dont le Premier ministre Ludovic Orban souligne que "l'État de droit est une protection importante pour garantir que l'argent des contribuables est dépensé de manière juste et efficace"

## Les perspectives de résolution
L'UE explore des "solutions pratiques" via des "clarifications techniques", selon Clément Beaune, secrétaire d'État français aux Affaires européennes. En dernier recours, l'UE pourrait envisager "d'avancer sans les pays qui bloquent".

Le sujet devrait être abordé lors d'un sommet par visioconférence initialement prévu pour discuter de la crise du Covid-19.

# 运动性尿失禁的预防与处理
*文／邹颉龙*  
*2019-05-04*

## 引言
近年来，我注意到因尿失禁就诊的患者族群越来越年轻，并不是尿失禁年龄层下降了，而是现在的女性重视健康，经常运动，因为运动而产生的尿失禁深感困扰。

## 案例分享
患者是一名40多岁女性，扎著俏丽的马尾，一袭黑色的运动服，看起来简洁俐落。一进诊间就说：「我生过两个小孩，最近孩子大了，比较有自己的时间，迷上健身运动。不过当在我做有氧运动跳跃的时候，竟然会漏尿…最近慢跑的时候也会漏尿，这样正常吗？」

## 运动与尿失禁的关系
要保持适当的体重还有良好的体能，运动是不可或缺的。问题是，许多运动都可能增加腹部压力，引发漏尿。

### 容易引发漏尿的运动
- 蹦床（弹簧跳床，trampoline）
- 跳远
- 体操（包括有氧运动时跳跃的动作）
- 跑步
- 篮球
- 举重：腹部压力上升，引发应力性尿失禁

### 适合尿失禁患者的运动
- 游泳：在水中进行的活动能够避免地心引力的影响，对于妇女的骨盆器官不会有冲击
- 高尔夫球

**The Reality of Driverless Cars: A Critical Analysis**

The introduction of driverless cars raises significant concerns about safety, practicality, and cost. While proponents tout their technological advancement, several crucial questions emerge: How would our roads change if driverless cars became commonplace? What are the real risks of accidents? And perhaps most importantly, what would be the true cost for average households?

Safety remains a paramount concern with autonomous vehicles. Accidents, while potentially reduced, cannot be completely eliminated. The question of accountability becomes particularly complex: when accidents occur, determining fault becomes challenging. If a conventional vehicle collides with a driverless car, the financial implications could be substantial, especially if the other party cannot afford the repairs to sophisticated autonomous technology.

**Technical and Practical Limitations**
The technology presents several practical challenges. These vehicles require regular charging or consume fuel, potentially more frequently than conventional cars.

Never again would I make such a mistake. The cold, hard metal was gentle to the touch—my only solace in those moments. How could I have been so stupid?

I thought freedom should have been close. After several weeks of waiting, self-pity had no place in my mind. I had spent twenty minutes staring at the same crack on the wall outside my bunk, lost in thought, my mind racing with vengeance at the wheel.

Finally, a well-groomed uniformed woman approached my cell. "Your sentence is up," she said. "Arms to your side until you reach the desk in C hall."

Had it really been 60 days? It didn't matter—I was free again. I walked as instructed, arms at my sides, focused on one thing: getting back to business.

At the desk, I waited as the officer stepped behind the fiberglass window. She returned my belongings: one cell phone and a bracelet inscribed with "conceive infinity"—probably the only thing I'd actually purchased from that corner market on 3rd and Wesston Ave. Why pay when you can take for free? Then came a fedora-style hat. "Ma'am, this isn't mine," I said. She chuckled, "Well, we don't know who you stole it from, so keep it."

I brushed off the remark. The woman, probably in her early forties with moderately frizzy blonde hair, carried that distinct jail smell: cold and wet.

Stepping outside a free man, I immediately spotted him—an elderly gentleman, likely in his eighties. Wisps of white hair clung to the sides of his balding head, and he walked with a pronounced hunch, leaning on a cane. Where was he headed? No matter. He was the perfect target, vulnerable as a ripe blackberry in the park.

I rushed forward, deliberately tripping his cane. As he fell, excitement surged through me, even as I offered apologetic words. While helping him up and brushing off his clothes, I smoothly lifted his black leather wallet. He smiled at my concerned inquiries, assuring me that accidents happen. I tipped my newly acquired hat, and we parted ways.

Two blocks later, brimming with satisfaction, I pulled the wallet from my back pocket and opened it to find... nothing. No money? Just insurance cards and—what's this? Several folded papers. The first revealed a black-and-white photograph of a handsome, light-haired soldier smiling beside a broken fence. Could this be the old man?

The second photo showed the same soldier holding a pistol to a man in striped fatigues. Something caught my eye—was that the Star of David on his arm? My breath caught. Surely this couldn't be the same gentle old man?

In the third photo, the soldier's smile had transformed into something sinister, stretching unnaturally wide, eyes narrowed to slits. The striped man was now absent—no, not absent. My eyes traveled down the soldier's slightly bent right leg to his boot, which rested on the head of the striped man. A dark hole marked the victim's face just right of his nose, his body lying in a dark pool of his own blood.

Shaken, I searched the wallet further, finding a folded cloth, black and white with reddish specks. It felt crusty and carried a familiar odor, reminiscent of adolescent socks. Bodily fluids? I dropped it immediately. As it fell, numbers on the reverse caught my eye: 2989.

That number tugged at my memory. I retrieved the photo again, focusing on the striped man's chest. There, unmistakable, were the numbers: 2989.

To improve the logical flow and coherence of the text, I've restructured the content by grouping related ideas together and ensuring a smooth transition between sections. Here's the revised version:

---

Sign languages are the native languages of the Deaf and their primary medium of communication. As visual languages, they utilize multiple complementary channels, known as articulators, to convey information. This includes manual features such as hand shape, movement, and pose, as well as non-manual features like facial expressions, mouth movements, and the movement of the head, shoulders, and torso.

The goal of sign language translation is to either convert written language into a video of signs (production) or to extract an equivalent spoken language sentence from a video of someone performing continuous sign. However, in the field of computer vision, much of the work has focused on recognizing the sequence of sign glosses (Continuous Sign Language Recognition, CSLR) rather than the full translation to a spoken language equivalent (Sign Language Translation, SLT). This distinction is crucial because the grammar of sign and spoken languages is very different. These differences include different word ordering, the use of multiple channels to convey concurrent information, and the use of direction and space to convey relationships between objects. Simply put, the mapping between speech and sign is complex, and there is no straightforward word-to-sign mapping.

Generating spoken language sentences from sign language videos is a spatio-temporal machine translation task. Such a translation system requires solving several sub-tasks, which are currently unsolved:

1. **Sign Segmentation**: The system needs to detect sign sentences, commonly formed using topic-comment structures, from continuous sign language videos. This is trivial for text-based machine translation tasks, where punctuation marks separate sentences. Speech-based recognition and translation systems look for pauses, such as silent regions, between phonemes to segment spoken language utterances.

许志安在去年4月与黄心颖"安心偷食"事件曝光后，引起全城轰动。事后，他在记者会上痛哭认错，随即闭关反省，鲜少露面。经过14个月的停工期，许志安昨日终于重返幕前，为ViuTV音乐节目进行录制。他戴着婚戒现身，在受访时谈及妻子郑秀文（Sammi）。对于前绯闻对象黄心颖的前男友马国明最近与汤洛雯公开恋情一事，他表示已知悉但婉拒评论。

The intersection of technology and emotion recognition is revolutionizing how we understand student engagement in education. While humans naturally interpret facial expressions—smiles indicating happiness, frowns suggesting sadness, raised eyebrows showing surprise—computers can now analyze these cues with even greater precision. This technological advancement offers promising applications in educational settings, where understanding student reactions is crucial for effective teaching.

The technology works by creating a sophisticated 3-D computer model of the face, incorporating all 44 major facial muscles that mirror human expressions. This system can accurately identify six basic emotions: happiness, surprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness. Such precision in emotional recognition provides teachers with valuable insights into student engagement that might otherwise go unnoticed.

Student engagement remains a persistent challenge in education, with many learners struggling to maintain interest in traditional classroom activities. They often seek learning experiences that are both educational and engaging. This is where emotion-recognition technology becomes particularly valuable—it allows teachers to receive real-time feedback about student reactions to different teaching methods and materials. As noted in the research, teachers can then adjust their teaching approaches while maintaining the core curriculum content.

The Face on Mars was not created by aliens, as there is no supporting evidence to validate such claims. Scientific investigations of the formation have yielded no artifacts, texts, or symbols that would suggest artificial construction, let alone extraterrestrial origin.

The complete absence of artifacts in the surrounding landscape is particularly telling. If aliens had constructed this feature, it would be reasonable to expect some trace of their presence—tools, equipment, or other remnants of construction. Even if some items were lost or removed, the probability of eliminating all evidence of such a massive engineering project seems implausible.

If the formation had been artificially created, we would expect to find some form of marking or inscription. Any intelligent species capable of interstellar travel and massive geological engineering would likely leave intentional markers or signatures of their work. If human-made, these might be in English or other Earth languages. If truly alien, we would expect to find unknown scripts or symbols. However, no such markings—familiar or foreign—have been discovered.

The total absence of any symbolic markings is particularly significant. Advanced beings capable of such construction would likely want to communicate something about their presence or purpose. The fact that The Face bears no such markings strongly suggests it is a natural geological formation rather than an artificial construct.

# Une grande dame de l'athlétisme acadien prend sa retraite

*Stéphanie Doiron, détentrice du record provincial senior du saut en hauteur (1,78m)*

Une des figures emblématiques de l'athlétisme en Acadie tire sa révérence. Stéphanie Doiron, à 23 ans, annonce qu'elle est prête à tourner la page et à entamer un nouveau chapitre de sa vie.

Après une carrière brillante s'étendant sur près de douze ans, l'athlète laisse derrière elle plusieurs records. Elle est considérée comme la meilleure sauteuse en hauteur de l'histoire du Nouveau-Brunswick, détenant notamment le record provincial senior avec un bond impressionnant de 1,78m, réalisé en 2015 à Sherbrooke.

Bien que teintée d'une certaine mélancolie, sa décision est réfléchie. « J'y réfléchissais depuis un moment », confie-t-elle. « Je m'étais dit que si j'avais une bonne saison en salle, je poursuivrais peut-être pour la saison extérieure. Mais une blessure aux ischio-jambiers en septembre m'a contrainte à une période de réhabilitation. »

Sa dernière compétition s'est déroulée à Moncton la semaine dernière. « Je me sentais en excellente forme et j'ai réalisé une belle performance. Mon entraîneur était très satisfait. Cependant, c'est à ce moment précis que j'ai pris conscience de plusieurs choses. Physiquement, j'étais capable de sauter, mais la motivation n'y était plus. »

## Un palmarès remarquable

Depuis ses débuts à l'âge de 10 ans, son parcours est jalonné de succès :

# 疫情后的市场变革：改变与延续

## 一、外资态势趋缓
台股指数自3月19日触及8523点的阶段性低点后开始反弹，近期已攀升至年线附近。如一个月前预期，外资在第二季度可能转为净买入方，截至4月底，外资在上市公司的净买入额约达208亿元。然而，第二季度是否能持续保持买超态势，仍需约两个月时间观察。鉴于指数已反弹约2500点，中期上行空间收窄，本文将转而探讨市场的变与不变。

虽然新冠疫情尚未完全结束，但全球疫情形势逐渐趋于稳定。这一现象既令人欣慰也引发思考：欣慰的是疫情不再如初期般令人恐慌，但值得关注的是，待疫情完全结束时，全球环境或将发生根本性改变。

## 二、三大重要转变

### 1. 健康意识的提升
台湾有效的防疫措施使民众免受高确诊率和死亡率的困扰，这促使国人更加重视个人健康与安全。虽然防疫用品的需求可能不会持续维持高位，但健康意识的提升已成为不可逆转的趋势。

### 2. 产业趋势的转型
疫情加速了全球产业格局的转变。最显著的例证是4月原油期货价格首次跌入负值区间。这不仅反映了传统能源地位的动摇，也凸显了服务业崛起和技术进步带来的深远影响。正如《经济学人》所言，"数据（data）已取代石油成为世界最有价值的资源"。

### 3. 科技应用的普及
疫情期间的行动限制推动了视讯会议和网络购物等科技应用的普及。特别是在口罩预购系统的推动下，即使是年长者也逐渐接受并适应了科技带来的便利。

## 三、投资常态的延续
值得注意的是，某些投资规律始终不变：市场往往在恐慌情绪最浓时触底，优质企业的股价总是率先企稳回升。
